commentText: More and more corporations/firms have found out that cutting costs raise profits faster than raising sales, so they find all kinds of ways to cut it. The easiest one they found recently, is to slowly cut down on employment because they only want the bare minimum level of employees, just enough to make the product work.  Problem comes when everyone starts doing that to raise their share value, since less people are employed sales drop, then they cut even more employees to make up that loss. The cycle then repeats until the market collapses one day, but the government refuses to step in, instead opting to double down and make it collapse earlier because they don't care if the US falls they just need to be in power after the fall.

commentText: this is literally all the same advice i was given back in my senior year of high school: Network, spruce up your resume, talk to people, go to events, and take initiative. I don't know how many times I've done all of this. I can't count the times hiring managers YELLED at me for 'disrupting their work flow' because i was trying to take that step. Its not just AI, guys, people want to get rich, and the rich want to keep the poor under their thumb. I've been unemployed for a year and five months, with only ONE interview. Let me emphasize that. **ONE.** And I was not hired.  At this point America is just a scam. Always has been in times of crisis.

videoTitle: Why No One Can Get A Job Anymore
videoDescription: Thanks to Betterment for sponsoring this video! Get started, be invested, Sign up in minutes: ...
commentText: I closed my laptop two minutes into an interview. Posted as remote, anywhere in my province. The interviewer asked how my day was going so far, I said something about the weather in my city that day. They froze, then said something about needing to be onsite (which was 4hrs away) once a week. I reminded her the posting only indicated remote work and she apologized for it being incorrect. I mentioned that I had another application pending for the same org, and wondered if she knew anything about the status of it. When I told her the position title, she told me it was a duplicate posting just worded slightly different. I told her there was a $35k difference between the two job listings. She froze again and I left the call shaking my head. That was one of only five interviews I got out of 70+ applications in a year.

videoTitle: Why No One Can Get A Job Anymore
videoDescription: Thanks to Betterment for sponsoring this video! Get started, be invested, Sign up in minutes: ...
commentText: I drove 45 minutes and showed up to a job interview and told the people at the front desk that I was here for an interview.  They looked confused and asked me for the name of the person I was supposed to be interviewing.  I gave them the name.  A little bit later, that person came out and we went into a private room to start talking.  They told me that the job was "recently filled" and there wasn't anything currently open anymore, but that they liked my resume enough that they wanted to talk to me in-person for "potential future opportunities".  At this point, I was seething so hard, I wanted to yell at them for wasting my time or say something snarky to this hiring manager.  But I practiced self control and played along and did my best as if the job was open, all the while rage was boiling in my stomach;  I didn't want to burn any bridges in-case this company is my last resort down the line and they do have something open in the far future.    But what a waste of my time, my whole day was wasted on this that could have been spent searching/applying for more jobs or preparing for a real interview.

commentText: Hearing to tailor the resume for each job posting, on top of already tailoring the cover letter for each job post, sounds fine in a small scale. But is unbelievably exhausting in reality. A lot of us applying to hundreds of jobs are doing that. It feels like it's just a pure numbers game rather than anything else. No matter how perfect a resume, cover letter, skills/abilities you have, experience history, etc., none of that seems to matter in the grand scheme of things. It's either you know someone, are able to know someone (and they're also willing to give you the time of day, which many aren't), or you have the willpower and patience to send out an infinite number of applications just for the hope of hearing back from a small few. Sorry if this sounds defeatist, I do appreciate the discussion and the advice, but this just eats away at you to where you just don't feel human anymore.

commentText: What is wrong with the job market? We‚Äôre in a government policy induced economic crash. The federal government has purposefully crashed the economy to forestall entitlement reforms, tax reform, immigration reform, and industrial policy reform. Any reforms would risk uprooting entrenched financial positions so they‚Äôre crashing the economy instead. AI should be a boon for productivity but that can only happen during economic growth periods. So that‚Äôs why the AI is fundamentally useless. AI allows people to do more work to less knowledge, but when the government increases inflation by printing money while simultaneously making it more and more expensive to hire and import, we get an economic crash instead of an uptick in quality of life. By the end of 2028 there will be a full blown economic depression similar to 2008, or perhaps even worse.

videoTitle: Why The Job Market Is On The BRINK Of Collapse
videoDescription: For Gen Z workers, entering the labor market has never been more difficult. What should be the natural next step after ...
commentText: I've been to Walmart for 2 years.  It's tough. Even at minimum wage, I had management riding me nonstop to be faster every night I worked.  This was a minimum wage job, yet they treated it like Amazon warehouse where they keep pushing you every day you work to be faster and do more in less time.  I was written up for the dumbest stuff.  One night I was stocking I had 4 mixed pallets on one end of my aisle and 1 pallet of just my stuff at the other.  Management called me to the office and said they're writing me up for not working because that 1 pallet is still sitting there at the end of my aisle.  I explained he obviously didn't see the other 4 mixed pallets which my stuff on top buried everyone else's stuff underneath so I was trying to move that off and stock it because you're not supposed to leave boxes strewn across the floor.  Management said they didn't see it and apologized, but said they still had to write me up because they had already called me to the office and it would look bad on them for pulling me away from my work for nothing.  That was back in 2015.  I'm sure Walmart is a lot harder today.  I changed jobs went to a grocery store doing minimum wage.  The grocery store refused to provide benefits, so everyone was scheduled less than 20hrs/wk.  I had just graduated from college (in my 30s) and had 10 years of customer service/retail exp under my belt and they treat me like I'm below the high school kids they were hiring that sit around drinking gatorade and playing on their phones.  Anyway, minimum wage jobs for the past 10 years couldn't afford an apartment, and I'm sure nowadays they can't either.  My old apartment up near the university was across the street from the grocery store used to be $600/month.  Today, it's practically doubled in rent, and the neighborhood now has a lot of problems with drugs.  A nice apartment in that university town you're looking at paying $3k+ for a single.  I left to China in 2019 because I couldn't find a job with my BA degree from the university right there in that town.  The Career Center at the university kept telling me to apply for GEICO insurance because they just opened new offices and needed help.  Her husband worked there.  I applied and went through round 1 of interviews 3 times.  They always ghost me after that.  So one day I called GEICO and asked to speak with the HR because I really wanted to know yes or no whether I got the job.  They told me the HR will be working on Thursdays.  I called back on Thursday, and the HR was out of town down in Florida on a family vacation.  I'm sitting there like, "you could have told me she was going to be out of the office this thursday, call back next thursday, but you didn't."  Felt like they just were making up stories and the job postings on Indeed might have been fake to appear like they're hiring when they were not.  I was also upset with the career center for not helping me find work.  You would think the school would be helping graduates find work because it'd show that their university degrees actually have value!  Instead, they didn't help me.  I had to go out and find my own job teaching in China.  I wish I could end there, but covid started 6 months after I arrived.  Their visa situation was chaos and my visa expired during a lockdown, so I couldn't get another work visa and I had to return home.  Now I'm jobless, living at home, taking care of my grandmother that was recently diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.  If she goes into a nursing home, we'll lose the house.  I've tried finding work when I came home from China, but employers just laugh me out the door.  The only type of job hiring right now is heavy industrial, and I don't have any heavy industrial skills.  I'm an academic, not a tradesman.  You say the job market is on the edge?  I'd say it's already collapsed when even young generation are struggling to find entry level positions and salaries everywhere are not keeping up with inflation and the rising cost of living.

commentText: I live in St Petersburg Florida, which has seen unprecedented migration from all over the country. It went from being a sleepy little town to a packed metropolis. Despite that, at the same time every business is closing, cutting hours or laying people off. A Wendy's just closed, a Checkers just closed. Village Inn cut hours, IHOP cut hours. The local ice cream shop that's been around since the 60s closed, the local burger place that's been open since the 60s closed. Home Shopping Network closed. For the first time since the 1970s we don't have a 24-hour or even late night grocery store. I know people with multiple college degrees who have been looking for a job for the past 6 months with no luck. There are homeless people everywhere. When I do ride sharing I take people with full-time jobs home to efficiency apartments, trailer parks and motel rooms.  The average studio apartment is over $2,000. I'm pretty sure that there's a crash coming any moment now.

commentText: I have applied to over 300 jobs since beginning of July 2025. Ive had maybe 10 call backs for interviews. What blows my mind the most is how many emails I've gotten saying the job I applied to is "on hold" "closed" or rescinded due to a change of mind in hiring someone. To me, most job postings these companies are not really hiring. Don't take it personal, you are not alone if you are looking for work and applying like I have.

I would recommend to anyone that is employed at a single job, go and get certified in other fields while you have the opportunity. commentText: The economy is suffering due to poor fundamentals.  These include the overall phenomenon called "structural unemployment."  Some economists have predicted this for decades because of its Malthusian essence.  Too many people, not enough jobs.  It will never return to what was.  It's not part of normal economic cycles that the experts are so fond of citing. It's exacerbated by AI and robotics.  Unless the government was proactive in planning to make society more socialistic, and improving conditions for citizens, then it's a down hill slide towards a plutocracy. Unfortunately that's the widening chasm between the rich and the poor, leaving the mid-class in tatters trying to maintain their standard of living in a country where the average person is involved in a non-consensual relationship with an economy hell bent on fleecing the shit out of people.  The automobile is the biggest fraud ever perpetrated on a populace. Just add up all the costs inherent in the operation of your car and hang up and drive.  The fender bender industry wants you on your phone, with headlights unique to each model and absurd prices for injection molded parts with insane margins. Back to the acyclic economic milieu in which we exist.  The end of the petroleum age means that we are seeing prices rise based on a truer calculation of embedded costs.   The slow death of urban core retail means that commercial real estate is getting shitty, and that sector has anchored funds and such for years.   Bankers are slow to adjust. Every company is squeezing everything for revenue, meaning the firings and the terrible job market are the tip of the iceberg. The guy who got voted in isn't doing anything to help you folks that believed the rhetoric.  He just wants to aggrandize himself and his cronies by reviving the polluting of our country while bad mouthing renewable energy because of its effect on the "landscape."   Since when has he given a shit about the natural world? Has he visited an open pit mine recently.  He has doubled his net worth over the last 6-18 months, while most US citizens are suffering.   Make no mistake: He doesn't give a shit about any of us, unless you're part of the war machine dominated by the Big 5 and go to Davos or Tetons.   Over Easter he dismissed us all and said "just enjoy your life" in a display of such callous indifference the average person's plight as to be obscene. He has begun to take away the basic right to free speech and his attacks on people smarter than he is who criticize what is happening is truly frightening.  We should all be very concerned and petition our generally greedy representatives who are often focused on their own inside information making their assisted stock market picks way easier. Stop attacking people who you might call liberal and understand that it will require all of us to find accord and quorum to achieve any progress.   Infighting and factionalism will be our downfall.

Next, is it possible that industry has manipulated these numbers for their benefit? We have had price inflation, this by the way, doomed the Democrats election chances and brought Trump to power. Could industry which claimed labor prices were a driver for price inflation were intentionally mis/under reported and claimed as a reason for inflation? That misreporting could've covered the fake reason for price inflation, and the fleecing of American consumers. Keep in mind that the BLS is only as good as the data that is REPORTED and there is no penalty for fabrication of numbers of jobs generated. It's up to the states and industry to insure that the correct numbers are reported. Finally, we have revisions every quarter and now the revisions for the year are revised downward? Something that needs to be investigated, but more likely than not won't be by the Trump Administration. Trump will likely blame the Biden Administration, without support, and not mention that the data provided that was the basis of the initial and revised reports were provided by industry itself. commentText: Bright does NOT track every single home sale in the region via their Multiple Listing.  It tracks sales and listing from members.  For example, you can have a "pocket" listing that closes in a day via a private communication and that property never hits the Bright MLS and a good agent will post the sale in Bright even though the property was never listed publicly.  Private sales not advertised on Bright are another example where that sale does NOT show up on Bright.

commentText: Earlier this year we closed our family-owned (since 1947) commercial construction company in a specialty trade, putting over 70 people out of work.   Most of our union workers made over $125k per year.   Hiring skilled, experienced people had always been a challenge.   In the 12 months prior to our shutdown, we lost over 20% of our employees that fled the area due to crime, and cost of living.   Recutting from out of state was impossible due to crime, and cost of living.  Our normal backlog was between $6,000,000 and $12,000,000.   With the commercial occupancy space rate at 33% and climbing, zero new commercial construction, and occupied space declining as leases expire, on the date we announced the decision to close, our backlog was less than $500,000, 50% of our monthly break-even billing.  Well done seattle & WA state leaders!

videoTitle: Job cuts rise nationwide, but experts say AI isn‚Äôt the main cause | FOX 13 Seattle
videoDescription: Companies across the U.S. are announcing layoffs they blame on artificial intelligence, but labor data shows most cuts stem from ...
commentText: So tired of the "automation won't replace humans, but work with them" nonsense. Entry-level today, mid/late career tomorrow, C-suite the next day. Starting with the great decoupling in the 1970s, human labor has been and will continue trending to zero. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY. Automation and robotics will necessarily replace human workers due to the current economic system. Think about this-today, AI is the WORST it will ever be going forward. It DOESN'T MATTER if AI "creates" 200 million new jobs...AI will solve and execute these new "jobs" much faster than humans will be able to adapt, learn, and fill them. Capital/employee model-it worked great...for quite a while. However, now companies that automate lower their costs, become more competitive. Those that keep higher-cost human labor necessarily fall behind and will go out of business. This creates a system where replacing people with machines is not just likely, but necessary for company survival. There is a way to deal with this humanely, but it would require a full revamp of the social contract and our concept of work. Even capitalists will want this change when unemployment reaches a tipping point and there‚Äôs no one left with money to buy the crap they‚Äôre selling.  I know, LLMs are leveling off, "what about the energy?," blah, blah, blah. Do not conflate LLMs with AI. LLMs are no more AI than vacuum tubes are computers or AOL dial-up is the internet. So, LLMs are leveling off. History shows technological advance is not just one sigmoid curve. It's a series of sigmoid curves with each successive one reaching new capabilities and new heights. To think that after 200,000 years, this pattern is all the sudden going to stop is absurd. I also understand there will be new jobs for humans created, it will go in this pattern: Automation creates 5 new jobs this year, lays off 30; creates 5 new jobs next year, lays off 500; creates 5 new jobs the following year, lays off 1500 etc. In the macro economic picture, do you not see this as an issue? I also understand there is more opportunity for entrepreneurs. Again, from the macro perspective there is a MINORITY of people that have the entrepreneurial ability/spirit. It takes that, and a strong majority of people don't have it.  Reasoning AI Is the Next Big Leap. The future of AI is not just about generating answers, but about ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù breaking down complex problems step-by-step, more like a human brain. Breakthroughs like DeepSeek‚Äôs open-source reasoning models are already being incorporated into platforms like GPT and xAI, marking a shift toward more advanced, thoughtful AI. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY.  There‚Äôs a persistent and misleading narrative circulating often perpetuated by short term goal-driven institutions like politicians, universities, and tech company executives, that the future of work is secure. The claim goes: ‚ÄúYou just need to learn how to work with AI,‚Äù and humans collaborating with AI will outperform either one alone. But recent research, including a landmark study from the University of Virginia, tells a different story. In diagnosing medical conditions, AI alone achieved far greater accuracy than either human doctors or even doctors assisted by AI. The median diagnostic accuracy for the docs using Chat GPT Plus was 76.3%, while the results for the physicians using conventional approaches was 73.7%. Sounds like ‚Äúa win‚Äù at first. However, Chat GPT Plus alone achieved a median diagnostic accuracy of more than 92%. In other words, the comforting idea that humans will always be essential partners to machines is crumbling. In many fields, AI is not just a tool, it is the superior performer. This has staggering implications for the future of work, especially to the often used solution of prior technological displacement that go ‚ÄúYou just need to be retrained.‚Äù To the group advocating the "retraining solution," I pose to you this: You have a medical doctor, just finished 8 years of higher education, a low-paid 4-year internship/residency, is hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt, and just got outperformed by automation; what would you have this doctor retrained into that will offer a secure job?  The result of this, since the United States' moronic system is based on taxing employees for about 70% of all tax revenue, this will further exacerbate the problem. Tax needs to be based on what's going on now and in the future not what worked 75 years ago. Oh I know it's so evil to think, but we might need to tax the companies who are doing the automation. Even if you do that, it's a win-win. For instance say a company had 1,000 employees in automated away down to 100. 1,000 employees paid federal taxes, including payroll tax, of about 20 million a year. Now the 100 people pay about 2 million a year. However, by automating, the company sees two things: they are no longer paying approximately 60 million in wages and their share of payroll tax, AND since nobody automates to lose money they also have higher profits. What's so wrong about taxing that company for the $60 million dollars they don't have to pay anymore and a fair percentage of their additional profits they now make through the automation. Not all the additional profits, but some of them. If you do that there's a higher tax revenue and more profits for the company. That's a win-win for the government and for businesses. If humanity, as a whole, weren't so stupid, we would just adjust as tech progresses to where EVERYONE benefits somewhat from each stage and just move smoothly into the post-labor economy.  To understand this shift, consider the historical role of the horse and oxen. They were once essential to the economy as sources of power for agriculture, transport, and industry. Technologies like the horse collar and the steel plow dramatically increased their output, making them even more valuable. But then came the steam engine and, later, the internal combustion engine. These machines didn‚Äôt just help the horse, but outperformed it entirely. Trains, tractors, and trucks could do the job ten, even a hundred times faster and more powerfully. And from that moment forward, the horse was no longer critical to economic output. It was, in essence, unemployed.  This is what AI and robotics are doing to human labor. They are not simply replacing the repetitive or the physical; they are increasingly outperforming humans in cognition, strategy, design, and communication. And just like the horse, our value in the economic system will diminish, not from lack of talent or effort, but because machines will do the job better. That‚Äôs why we need to start thinking not in terms of retraining, but about restructuring society itself for a world where human labor is no longer essential to production. When the very essence of what makes an entity useful to the current economy is superseded (be that strength, endurance, dexterity, analysis, creativity, empathy, intelligence, persuasion as well as many other qualities) that entity becomes irrelevant to economic output.  Potential solution. Decentralized AI Ownership: A Bridge Toward Post-Scarcity. While Universal Basic Income (UBI) may serve as an initial economic stopgap, bridging today‚Äôs economy with tomorrow‚Äôs abundance consider an even more equitable and long-term solution: Decentralizing the ownership of artificial intelligence itself.   Rather than concentrating the power of AI in the hands of a few corporations or governments, envision a model where AI entities are open-source and collectively owned. This could take the form of assigning each person a digital "share" of an AI system, not unlike a stakeholder‚Äôs share in a company. As the AI produces value, whether through intellectual labor, creative output, or autonomous economic participation, those shares would generate dividends distributed directly to individuals.   This model would ensure that as AI becomes the dominant productive force in society, the wealth it creates is shared universally, not monopolized. It aligns with the principle that the fruits of public knowledge made possible by centuries of human collaboration should benefit everyone, not just a few early adopters or private entities. In practice, this could look like:   - AI systems running Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) that distribute profits algorithmically. - Smart contracts ensuring transparent, equitable income flows based on collective stake. - Global ‚ÄúAI cooperatives‚Äù where users vote on how AI is used, improved, and deployed. - Universal basic compute.   If AI becomes the primary driver of economic output, then equitable access to its benefits isn‚Äôt just fair, it‚Äôs necessary to avoid deepening inequality and instability. It provides a scalable, technologically aligned extension to UBI, ensuring people not only have income, but true economic participation in the age of intelligent machines.   Ultimately, decentralized AI ownership may be the last transition phase before full post-scarcity, when advanced technologies like universal nanofactories or matter compilers render even economic structures obsolete. Until then, however, models like this offer a way to reclaim agency in a world where production no longer requires human hands, and where wealth can, for the first time in history, truly be universal.

commentText: We have to remember there was a huge surge in tech hiring during the pandemic. Now companies are letting people go or not hiring to level things out. This is also amplified due to massive increase in capex spending for AI infrastructure.  Companies are not hiring or doing layoffs because of previous over hiring and increases in spending.  When rates go down (and they will because the government needs to refinance their debt), this is going to create more investment (probably in AI or other tech areas) which will create more hiring.   The thing is, once rates drop, they will likely stay low for some time because the government wants higher inflation to erode their newly refinanced debt. It's the only option to decrease their debt to GDP.
